headline: CNN NewsNight with Abby Phillip
subHeadline: Trump's Lies Grow Around Distribution Of FEMA Hurricane Relief; Trump And Gov. Brian Kemp (R-GA) Meet For First Time Since 2020 Feud; U.S. Economy Added 254,000 Jobs in September; Oklahoma Requires Classrooms To Have Bibles; Trump Campaign Focuses On Immigration. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Officials warn Donald Trump's lies --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Their money's been spent on people that should not be in our country.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: -- mean life or death for Helene-hampered communities as the former president has a not so meet cue with a former foe.Plus, the president gives a glass half full take on the election, that it'll be on the level -- JOE BIDEN, U.S. PRESIDENT: I'm confident it'll be free and fair.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: -- but warns it might turn violent.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I don't know whether it'll be peaceful.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Also, a boom, jobs and wages pop off as the calendar turns to the final month of the campaign.And Donald Trump returns to the scene of a near national tragedy, Butler, Pennsylvania. Live at the table, Maria Cardona, Abel Maldonado, Erin Perrine, Bomani Jones and Roy Wood Jr. With 31 dates to go, Americans with different perspectives aren't talking to each other, but here they do. (END VIDEOTAPE) PHILLIP (on camera): Good Friday evening to you. I'm Abby Phillip in New York. Let's get right to what America is talking about, storms, lies and videotape. The former president has an election to win in just about a month, and with 31 days until America votes, it's pretty clear that he is willing to break the rules and the truth to do it. The latest episode, his plainly false insistence that the Biden administration is starving people stuck and struck by this storm. Hurricane Helene, they are in desperate need of resources, and here is what Trump is saying about it. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: People are dying in North Carolina. They're dying all over those five, six states. They're dying and they're getting no help from our federal government, because they have no money, because their money has been spent on people that should not be in our country.They stole the FEMA money just like they stole it from a bank. It's been a terrible response from the White House. They're missing a billion dollars that was used for another purpose and nobody's seen anything like that. You have the migrants, you're reading about it. Now, a lot of the money that was supposed to go to Georgia and supposed to go to North Carolina and all of the others is going and has gone already. It's been gone for people that came into the country illegally. They're missing a billion dollars that they gave to migrants coming into our country. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: If you can believe it, none of that is true. That was a lot of lies in a few seconds. Why does Donald Trump continue to insist on politicizing the storm that is actively still occurring, people are still in need of help, and lying about it so consistently?FMR. LT. GOV. ABEL MALDONADO (R-CA): Abby, I don't see him politicizing this storm. He is down there showing that he's the leader.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But he's claiming that Biden is withholding aid because these people are, I guess, presumptively Republicans. That's just patently false.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: I think President Trump is down there making a very big point and raising the flag of this state needs a lot of help, and he's making a point.The one thing that you can't accuse of him not being is a leader. And during these storms, Abby --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But he's -- I mean, Lieutenant Governor, with all due respect, he is lying. He is lying. MADLONADO

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Here's the great irony -- hang on a second. Here's the great irony of the situation. Trump is saying that FEMA right now is taking money that was supposed to go to disaster relief and using it for migrants. That is not true. But here is what Trump did. Biden take -- this is the headline from The Washington Post. Biden didn't take FEMA relief money to use on migrants. Trump did. In 2019, the Trump administration, in the middle of a hurricane, told Congress that it was taking $271 million from the DHS programs, including $155 million from disaster relief to pay for immigration detention space. He did that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: How can you forget?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Exactly. And so when he talks about, when he makes out of whole cloth, these ridiculous lies about the administration, which Republican governors have actually said, no, they are getting what they need from this administration, we have talked to President Biden, we have talked to Vice President Harris, they are responding absolutely adequately, more than adequately, we're getting what we need.Meanwhile, When Trump was president, he gutted FEMA. He did not want to give California the aid that they needed from wildfires until they had to show him a map that the places that needed the help were Republican. It is absolutely insanity what this man is doing. He's not just politicizing the storm but he's putting people's lives in danger.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It takes a lot of nerve to do this during a hurricane. I mean, Erin, I know you're laughing, but it really -- I mean, I wonder, though, like, is it just because he's like I've got to do whatever it takes, we've got 31 days left, you know, all bets are off?

utterances.speaker: ERIN PERRINE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST, AXIOM STRATEGIES
utterances.sentences: I learned a long time ago to not try and really delve into the deep thinking that goes into Donald Trump's head because that was never our role. We were just always there to never explain but just to let his answer stand. So, trying to explain this is beyond even those words for him.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Once or twice I heard the tweet speaks for itself.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm sure you will (INAUDIBLE). But we will give Donald Trump credit here. He has been trying to raise money privately as well for disaster relief. He is trying to stand up as an individual citizen to make sure that there is some relief available. But this is such a missed opportunity for this country to come together.If it had been Kamala Harris or Donald Trump, who said, everybody swords down, what we can do right now is in a bipartisan fashion, stand together and say, let's do a big concert fundraiser. Let's find a way to bring more money into the Red Cross or to other disaster relief organizations and put the swords out. But nobody on either side of the political spectrum decided to say, you know what, this is a moment for true leadership. But, hey, let's have aspirational beliefs in all of our politicians.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I don't know why you're bringing Kamala Harris into this. The only person who is politicizing this is Donald Trump. He's the one guy doing it.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: I'm not arguing the premise of what you're saying there, but what I'm saying is an opportunity for both sides to be better than they were in this situation. Because, ultimately, if you want to show leadership, if Kamala Harris is standing there saying, I'm the difference, I'm the other option, I'm the adult in the room, there was an opportunity right there to do it, but she didn't. And I'm not going to --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me --

utterances.speaker: BOMANI JONES, PODCAST HOST, THE RIGHT TIME WITH BOMANI JONES
utterances.sentences: Look, this isn't complex. When Trump thinks he has an issue that is a winner for him, he is going to pound everything into that issue. He thinks immigration is the issue that matters. So, everything's going to go back to immigration.Now, I do find it fascinating and interesting. He's real bad with what if money, right? Like this is one of the things about the pandemic. That's a what if situation. The disaster stuff is a what if situation. He don't think that far, right? So any money that's supposed to be for the what if is money that he will have historically diverted into something else. I'm sure his people know that at some point somebody was going to say, hey, you know, Trump was the one that kind of got rid of some of this what if money for something like this. So, what do you do? You just redirect it and talk about the thing that you think wins and that you think you can fool people into saying, no matter what, this money is gone toward immigration. That's going to be the line that he pounds for a month because it's the one thing I think he thinks he can win on.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Where is President Trump today? He's down there. He's showing leadership, Bomani.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I don't feel like going down there and showing leadership.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: He's taking advantage of the situation.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: When you have a disaster like this, and you are the leader, I got to tell you, people want to see you down there. The people are hurting. People have passed away. They want you down there.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: He doesn't care about the people. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: You know, this notion that if they go down there, it's a distraction, that is not the case. That is not the case.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: No. Somebody running for president should go down there. I'm just telling you, ain't everybody happy.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Well, to be fair, Governor Kemp did have to push back on him. Originally, only 11 of the counties in Georgia were declared disaster counties. He had to call back into the White House and to FEMA and say, hey guys, you're ignoring some of the rural counties here. Can you look again? Then the number went up to 41. So to be --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: They responded.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: but I'm saying (INAUDIBLE), let's be clear --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It sounds like a very normal interaction between a state and federal government.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: But it wasn't from the jump. There were consistent conversations and Republican governors had to go back on behalf of their states and advocate for more.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: but they got what they needed. And here --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let's just let Brian Kemp speak for himself.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) GOV. BRIAN KEMP (R-GA): The president just called me yesterday afternoon. I missed him and called him right back. And he just said, hey, what do you need? And I told him, you know, we got what we need. He offered that if there's other things we need just to call him directly. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It sounds like he did exactly that and the problem was resolved.But speaking of Brian Kemp, the other person that Donald Trump was spending some time with is him. And they have not always had the best relationship. The --

utterances.speaker: WOOD
utterances.sentences: He couldn't find votes for him.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Right, Donald Trump couldn't find the 11,000 votes that he asked for. But the interaction today, I just thought it was really fascinating to watch these two men who -- Trump has spent so much time criticizing Brian Kemp publicly and now they're shaking hands.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: What does that tell you? What does that say?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I think we have the video, right?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: That he's a hypocrite and he's -- that's exactly what he felt.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Here's the handshake. It's one of those --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: that tells me that Governor Kemp is really pushing for Donald J. Trump to become the next president of the United States. And, obviously, he's afraid of having Kamala's economy come into play. So, he's going to do whatever he can to help Donald J. Trump. They're -- today, that image was images, we're working strong for Georgia.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Or is he just entertaining the possibility that Donald Trump might become the president at which point you might want to shake his hand the last time.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I actually think it's the flipside. I think that Donald Trump --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Well, he needs it more.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No, exactly. I think that Donald Trump is really concerned about what's happening in Georgia. He is seeing the numbers. He is seeing Kamala Harris' rallies. He is seeing the early vote and it is all -- Democrats are doing really well. And so he says to himself, oh my God, a month ago, I was absolutely down on Kemp, and I was insulting the guy a month ago. Now, I'm going to have to go and suck up to him, or else I am toast.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: It's not sucking up. It's working together for the people of Georgia and for the people of North Carolina.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Then how come -- then why was it different a month ago when he was insulting Kemp?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: It's politics.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No, it's Donald Trump's politics.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Today is not politics. We have a natural disaster day.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Just in case anybody at home is confused about what we are talking about here, here's the video of Brian Kemp and Donald Trump over the last couple weeks.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: He didn't grin?

utterances.speaker: WOOD
utterances.sentences: No, he didn't grin.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No, he did not, exactly.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Your governor and your secretaries of state, they're petrified of Stacey Abrams.What they have done to your state, I think most people have no idea what they've done to your state. I'll be here in about a year-and-a-half campaigning against you, Governor, I guarantee you that. No, we work together. We've always worked together very well, very, really well. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: All the time.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No, I'm sorry, it doesn't.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: All the time on both the Republican side and on the Democrat side.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: It doesn't even happen with Republican politics. It happens with Donald Trump politics.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: He's not a politician though. You got to admit he's not a politician.(CROSSTALKS)

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: He's a leader and he's a businessman. He's not a politician. JONES

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm just going to throw that out there.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Do you think four years are going to change him as a businessman? No, he's a businessman. He's not a politician.

utterances.speaker: WOOD
utterances.sentences: If there's no hurricane, is Trump trying to make --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: And that's what people love about him. He's not a politician.

utterances.speaker: WOOD
utterances.sentences: If there's no hurricane, is Trump trying to make peace with the governor of a battleground state?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Of course, he was before, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: A month ago, he was calling him a loser. That's trying to make peace with him?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Erin, go ahead. Hang on, Maria. Hang on. Go ahead, Erin.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: To the premise of your question, would Donald Trump be working with a Republican governor of a battleground state in the last 60 days leading up to the election, whether or not he likes him or lumps him? Absolutely, whether or not there was the hurricane or not.Regardless of that, of course, Brian Kemp has an incredibly strong ground game and institutional knowledge of that state. And while Donald Trump may not like Brian Kemp all the time, and I'm sure that might go both ways, but I'm not going to judge either man on their personal opinion of each other, they will, of course, work together to be able to turn on that ground game, because at the end of the day, Brian Kemp is supporting Donald Trump and not Kamala Harris.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: He's using him.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And the only reason --

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: You guys are suspending the political reality.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: And that is big on both of them are. That is big on both of them to come together and --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: If elections are really about the economy, stupid, then consider this really good news for Kamala Harris. Today's monthly jobs report, it was a blockbuster. Just listen.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We came in much hotter than expected on the non- farm jobs number, 254,000 jobs were created.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This comes with the election 32 days away and the economy remains the top issue.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Wow. That's pretty amazing. So, those are really good numbers, very good numbers. So, you know, they'll be talking about that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Better than expected, yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I just hope these are the actual numbers and they're not adjusted again. But if it is, then it's a good win for the country.

utterances.speaker: LOU BASENESE, PRESIDENT, MDB CAPITAL
utterances.sentences: I'm an optimistic guy, but I got to be honest. I thought there'd be more red flags than had a communist parade in this report and there's not a single one. There's not one data point in here that I can point to that's not good.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Those are some pretty glowing reviews of this latest jobs report, but Donald Trump says don't believe any of it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Inflation has devastated our economy. It's one of the big problems we have. And on jobs, we have -- the illegals have taken more jobs than anybody else. You have illegals coming in and they're taking the jobs. And when you look at the numbers from that standpoint, it's a shame. We have to get the jobs to the people that have lived here for a long time. And they are great, great citizens of our country. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It's a good jobs report. And this is really -- I mean, we'll have one more before the November election. But I think the signs are pretty clear. When you talk to economists, the economy is doing well. The chances of recession have pretty much passed. Those are the facts,

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: But you might talk to economists and they say that, but that's still not getting to the American people every day. And while mortgage rates might be coming down and there might be strong economic numbers, including jobs numbers, which is a great sign for the economy, every day, the American people see two numbers that they likely remember. It's the price of gas because they drive past the gas station every day and it's the price of groceries when they walk in.And when people are saying they can't afford chips anymore because they feel like a luxury item, even if the job numbers look good -- yes, like potato chips. Yes, I've heard a woman on the radio actually say that to NPR that she no longer buys chips because those feel like a luxury item to her because of how much costs have gone up and how restricted her budget is. Until the American people start to feel it while the headlines and the numbers are good, until the American people feel it, it's a very hard sell for Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: One of the interesting parts about this conversation, the reason I think it's important to have it now, is because the poll numbers also show Kamala Harris closed the gap with Donald Trump on the economy. Something is happening here where there is an appreciation for the economic reality among the electorate.That is also happening.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I think what's happening is that while there are still a lot of people that are hurting and Kamala Harris has been very smart to be speaking to those people to say, here's what I'm going to do to continue to drive down costs. But the reality is, and I've heard this in focus groups and you can see it in the closing of the gap on the economy, people are feeling better about their own situation. They are feeling better about what they can do with their families. It's not all there, but the fact that she speaks to the issues that people are still worried about, and we're seeing these numbers, and it also includes wages that are up, manufacturing is up, the stock market is through the roof, right, all of the indications are going in the right direction at the right moment.When everyone says, oh, it's the economy, stupid. Well, yes, okay. If that's what you believe, and it is true, these are the numbers that people are seeing and they are the numbers that people are starting to feel as well.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Look, we got two things, right? One, notice again, Trump tried to make that about immigration. That's the note that he's playing this week. But I contend that all the discussion about the economy, and we could talk about the larger reports that say everything else, people are not studying to figure out what the economy is. They don't care about the economy is about 100 million little economies everywhere and everybody cares about. Their own economy is my house. How am I doing now? The jobs numbers, like I think I saw this for, I think it was black people over 20 went from like 5.1 to -- 5.9 percent unemployment to 5.1, which is a crazy job to have in one month. Those are the things that people think about. If the economy got me a job that I didn't have before, you know, this economy thing ain't really as bad as I thought it was the other day.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: You're going to like it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Well, that happens -- well, hold on. Let me just -- hang on.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: We're sending a message to everybody, things are great. Things are not good in America.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me just clarify here.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Economic numbers, jobs numbers are almost always adjusted. They're adjusted up. They're adjusted down. The question is, what direction is the economy headed in? And it's been pretty clear after several months, including the adjustments, the direction is headed -- unemployment is going down, inflation is going down, jobs are going up, that is the direction.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: The last two months were adjusted up, Maria, more, more jobs.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: You said things are good. You said things are good. With all due respect, you said things are great, or good. Let me tell you something, things are not good in America. Real people are hurting out there today. Half of our population is broke.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I don't think you heard me, Abel. What I'm saying is that the economic numbers --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Everybody is waiting for Friday to pay the bills. They can barely pay the bills.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Bomani just made a really important point.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: What's that, Bomani?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It is true that people have been struggling in this country for a long time. Economic inequality has been going up and up for decades.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Like the greatest farce of American politics is all this talking to the middle class about how much you care about them and ignoring the fact that that becomes a smaller group. That's what everybody does. So, the idea that there are people struggling, there are. My point is the report is not going to answer the question. People are not waiting for the report to come out to be like, hey, guys, I think the economy is going okay. They're just looking around their own house. And if you got more -- and if the report indicates that more people look around their own worlds and see something better, that's the part that matters, not about the --

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: That is what is being indicated. And so --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I want to get Roy in here because this is a little bit just one of those Trump things, right? Today, I guess, in the midst of all of this, he decides to send out this message on his Truth Social, announcing, I should say falsely, that Jamie Dimon, the CEO of JPMorgan Chase, has endorsed him for president, forcing JPMorgan to say that's just not true.Trump -- the point being, and this is actually the other reason that this conversation is important, Trump was banking on an economic crash that is not happening.

utterances.speaker: WOOD
utterances.sentences: And that's why stories like this, I think, have less -- because you know, it's good for Democrats. Okay. Maybe, but the idea of you getting a job this month and the effects of it, and you coming out of getting the car out of repo, and you coming out of getting all the back bills paid, that's a December, January, February equation.So, when you look at the idea that you still have people that are dealing with a lot of debt and a lot of issues, I still think that lies are the main leverage to influence people. Like you can say this is good for Democrats, but the economy and the mood attached to that, that's a slow turning ship.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. It very much is.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: But that's why, that's why you have Kamala Harris smartly focused on those people who might not be feeling these numbers. And --

utterances.speaker: WOOD
utterances.sentences: Trust me, give me a few more months, and it's going to get better.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: And here's what I will do --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: That's why 48 percent --

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: The big problem for Democrats right now, if you look historically speaking about right track, wrong track in the country, when you poll it more broadly, right now is the incumbent party for Democrats where their number sits on wrong track is so high that no incumbent party has won the presidency in decades with a number this high. So, this is just something Democrats need to keep in mind. While the vibes might feel better for the party and they've got things that they can message on, the American people are telling you they are not feeling it.And I'm a Republican, so gosh darn, I don't get paged by Democrats to give them advice. But unless you're actually getting a way to sell that to the American people, they aren't really --

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: So you're right, that, normally, that number historically would say, okay, this party is going to lose because of the right track, wrong track number. Recently though, that wasn't the case in 2022. And, in fact, you asked so many Democrats --

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: But midterms and presidentials are different.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Understood. But still today, if you ask a lot of my Democratic friends, if things are going in the right direction in this country, they'll say, no. Are you going to vote for Kamala Harris? Absolutely, yes, because they feel --

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: You're just saying your Democrat --

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's what I'm telling you. They are some of the ones that are saying that the wrong track in this --

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: The vast majority of Americans, obviously.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Well, so what I'm telling you is it doesn't track with who they're going to vote for.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Put this one in the pantheon of grifts, Oklahoma is now requiring classrooms to have bibles. And now MAGA-friendly lawmakers are writing the rules to leave schools with just one option --one option to supply the good book. They are MAGA Bibles. Here's the story.The agency that runs Oklahoma's schools set out really specific guidelines for the Bibles that will ultimately be handed out to students. They have to be a King James Bible. They have to have the Pledge of Allegiance. They have to have the Declaration of Independence and they have to have the Old and New Testaments -- one would hope, and they have to have the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Well, his favorite book also costs $60. And there's another one that he has also endorsed that costs $90. And so, when you look at it, $3 million, about 50,000 books, that's a lot of money. And there's only one book that basically makes the cut. It's pretty incredible.WOOD JR.: Fabulous. That one like -- that one like silver or like hard-bound or something like that? Why is the we, the -- why is that one 90? Like, what extra do I get?

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: It's got all the Constitution. It's got the Declaration of Independence. You get Donald Trump's blessing.WOOD JR.: If I pay $90 for a bible, I'm going to heaven.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Or if it's Donald Trump's bible, you might go somewhere else.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Okay. I mean, look, a regular bible will set you back five bucks. Ten bucks. Maybe 20.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Three actually, on Amazon. You can get it at $3 on Amazon.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Let's just start with the very beginning of this, which was this Oklahoma decision to have to mandate Bibles in schools. Oklahoma students are struggling so much with math and reading and writing right now, as are lots of students across the United States because of being left behind because of the pandemic and limited resources and education at this point.The idea that we are now mandating the Bible be taught in school darned the separation of church and state. And I am a Republican and I own a bible. I can tell you this is not going on the right track. When I first heard this, I thought, okay, he's trying to make a move to get this to the Supreme Court, right? He's going to try and litigate this and make this a big case. But now that I'm seeing this Bible play on it, not only did I not like it in the first place because if we're not teaching our students how to be competitive in the global economy, we are not soothing our students at all. And that can also mean STEM. It can mean career technical training, can mean any number of things. But the Bible's on top of it. I don't like any of it. Teach kids what they need to know to succeed in America. This isn't hard.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And also, don't try -- I mean, I think the part of it where, it's been amazing. I mean, it's the shoes, it's the bibles. He's got $100,000 watches. I mean, I've never seen a presidential candidate, let alone a former president doing this kind of thing. where essentially it's just --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, hold on. Are we talking about him making this is his livelihood? No.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I'm just saying --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: This is a president --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: In the midst of him running for president, he's doing all of this. This is just unusual.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: He gave up his $400,000 salary and he gave it to charity.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's cool.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: So, he's not doing this for five bucks, six bucks. Come on.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Oh yes, because Trump don't do nothing for money. You're right.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: No. He just wants to give it all away.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: He doesn't care about money at all. He's Andrew Farley. You're right.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: For five bucks, Bomani?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's not five bucks. It's 60 bucks.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But look, here's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hang on.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: We're not talking enough about the fact that -- and I don't know what Trump gets from these things. I don't know how much Lee Greenwood gets, right? I know this. This is money going from the state to him in some form of fashion. We can't just roll our eyes and shrug that off. That is crazy to stop thinking about.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: But Bomani, I think we're setting the stage here that he's doing this money for him. We don't know that.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: He's getting some cut in it.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: But yet we're insinuating -- we're insinuating that it's money for him.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Well, let me ask you a question. Let me ask you a question.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Do you really think that President Trump needs money from a Bible for him? Then let go of the Bible's end. I mean, that's not President Trump's choice. That's the state. That's the education department in the State of Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hang on. If Trump didn't need the money then -- why does he bother to hawk all of these things? I don't I mean, I think you're right. I think you're right. Trump is extremely wealthy. He has a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But he is selling shoes --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Look what he did over there with the Hurricane Helene, with GoFund Me -- $6 million. He's raising it.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: GoFundMe --other people --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: -- and watches and bibles --

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: If I may -- if I may play Double Zep, they could hear also -- the man sells steak and wine.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You guys say he's so rich and then say he raised money out of GoFundMe.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: We don't know how much he's given, Bomani, but I'm sure he's given money. We don't know that.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: But let's remember two things. Let's remember two things.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hold on, Maria. Let me let Erin finish.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: To be clear, like, this is not the only thing Donald Trump sells. He has been a businessman. It has been wine and champagne and steaks and hats and shirts and bath bombs and soaps. This is not new for Donald Trump.So, while this might be different because he is a former president, if you put it in the more totality of who Donald Trump as a person, as a businessman, you can at least give it a little bit more sense.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Don't you think he should at least pause it while he's running for president?

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Listen, I've never seen a candidate sell and do this in this fashion before, but Donald Trump does plenty of things.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: It's incredibly unseemly because this is money. This is taxpayer money. And to your point, Erin, the state superintendent is in trouble because he has not gotten inhalers to the children in Oklahoma that suffer from asthma and instead, he's now going to spend this money on $60 bibles for Donald Trump. That's insidious.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Maria, Maria, we're talking about bibles in Oklahoma. We're talking about bibles in Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: But people can't even feed their families at home. Let's talk about jobs.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Do you think that's good government? Do you think that's good government?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I actually think -- that's a great point.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: That's not my -- okay. That's Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's a great point.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: That's Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's a great point. People are struggling.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: They're struggling.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Shouldn't the government be spending more?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: And we're talking about $5 --$40 bible.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. Shouldn't the government be spending its money on -- with helping those people?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: And on inhalers?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: That's the state of Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's what I'm asking.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: That's the state of Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: You used to be a state legislator.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Yes,

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: So, can you answer that question?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: I mean, as a state legislator in California, that would never happen. But in Oklahoma, that's a whole different state. That's just the way it is, Maria.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Because it's Trump, it's okay.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: No, it's not Trump.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Essentially, it's what you're saying. Are you kidding me? That's what you're saying.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: This guy --

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Anything that Trump does, you can excuse.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: President Trump got $400,000 a year, he donated and you think he's worried about making a little bit of money on the bible?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: All right, even if it's not him, all I'm going to say is, no Republicans ever going to balance the budget by a $60 bribe.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That's what you all be talking about.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about jobs.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Insidious governance.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Balance the budget, it's like we're back in the Paul Ryan era of politics.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Okay, well. All right, Roy.WOOD JR.: I don't understand. If Trump has a right to sell the bibles, fine, sell the Bibles. But don't tell me that this is a good idea by the state to do. And if you're going to do it, then buy the $5 Bible. Buy the used Bible. Go to the Motel 6. Steal bibles out the drawers.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Don't steal the bibles.WOOD JR.: Steal the bibles. Nobody uses those bibles. Okay, ask the hotel if you can borrow the bible.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. But I think the point we need to make here is that we're leaving the impression that it's the Trump bible and he's making money off the bible and it's always -- it's not that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Then what is it?WOOD J.: What is it?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: And of course he's making money off of it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Why do you think they specify the Trump Bible then?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Of course, I mean, I mean --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hold on, hold on, hold on. We -- once again, sorry. We have to go. But I just --just to be clear, I mean, we don't -- they have not explicitly said it's the Trump Bible, but there's only one bible that qualifies, and it is the Trump Bible, A. And B, Trump has endorsed it and is getting a cut from it. So, the fact -- those are the facts and we don't know --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: We don't know that, Abby. We don't know what the cut is.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We don't know what he's doing with it.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Right, we don't know that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But it's going to be.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: But we're insinuating that it is.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hang on, guys.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: That's the problem here.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: He's getting a cut.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Back in Butler tomorrow. Donald Trump is going to return to the very place where he almost lost his life after a would-be assassin's bullet missed him by mere inches. And when he arrives, he'll have some famous company with him, namely Elon Musk.Now, the ex-owner joined Trump in blaming rhetoric from Democrats for fueling the assassination attempt. But Musk, you can say, is throwing stones from a glass house. He also mused aloud about why someone wouldn't take a literal shot at President Biden or Vice President Harris. Now, Abel, I'm told that you will be there tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: What is Trump -- first of all, what is the purpose of this trip? And what is Trump going to say, you think? What should he say?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Well, I haven't talked to him about what he's going to say. But in my mind, I'd like to see him say, I'm here to finish my speech. And as I was saying, and he's going to finish his speech. That's what I see him doing.Look, in California, we had a president named Ronald Reagan who was shot. And it was very somber moment in our life. And he said that God saved his life and put him in a position of leadership to bring America back to greatness. And I think I see that with Donald J. Trump, to be very sincere with you. This is a man who was given a speech and whether you like him or not, he is a true American who loves his country. Somebody try to take his life. And here tomorrow, he's going to go back to a very special moment, and I just can't wait to see it, Abby, because I think it is historic, very historic. He's a fighter. He's a fighter. That's why he's going back. He's going to continue to fight for the American people. And I can't wait to see him tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: One of the other things is that Elon -- first of all, tomorrow will be 30 days until the election. So, there's that. It's a clean month. Elon also endorsed him immediately, pretty much after this assassination attempt. So, that might explain why he'll be there again.But what strikes me about this is that, certainly take what you're saying. I mean, this was honestly a pretty traumatic moment for the whole country. But Trump seems to really be explicitly leaning into the way that this will help him politically. Is that appropriate, you think?

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but I think that's not necessarily for me to say. I don't necessarily -- it wouldn't be my political instinct to go back there for a political speech. It would be my instinct to go back there and pay reverence to those -- the people who lost their lives there and to be able to say, to do something -- to do something for the community, right? In a way to be able to give back.I've hosted plenty of events that were --had politicians involved but were fundraising in nature for outside communities and for the community that they were in. There's an opportunity again here to unite and be bigger than the moment and be bigger than politics. Will he meet that moment? I can't tell you that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I bet you can't.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Guys, come on. Can we put the cynicism away for half a second and let me just finish the statement that, like, there is an opportunity here. And whether or not we actually think he meets the moment, it's fair enough to say it exists, and we should encourage everybody to say that it is.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hold on, Maria.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right. It goes from being like a moment for the country to just being a little bit --WOOD, JR.: The speeches of Deluxe album, you're going to get two new tracks. And then the rest of the day is going to be what we've already heard.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: It inevitably devolves when it has anything to do with Donald Trump. And we all know that his go-to move is to focus on immigration. I bet you he's going to talk about migrants and how they commit crimes and how they kill people. I guarantee you he's going to do that because now he has Elon Musk at his side.And Elon Musk has now adopted the xenophobic tropes that Donald Trump, including the lies, including the conspiracy theories, and he talks about that every single day on X. And the real ironic thing here is Elon Musk, when he first started pitching all of his businesses for his tech companies, he was undocumented. He was an undocumented immigrant here. So, a little hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Forty-eight percent of Latinos are supporting Donald Trump, Maria.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No, they're not. That's wrong.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Forty-eight percent of them are Latino.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: They're not. That's not true.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: So, he's going to continue to talk about immigration?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Maybe about 33 percent of Latinos are supporting Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It really would be a shame if Trump or Elon Musk, because both of them have done this, were to feed into these baseless conspiracies that, quote, unquote, "they were behind this". I mean, we know who was responsible for this and it's not a conspiracy. So, I mean, do you expect that Trump will rise to at least that occasion tomorrow?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: I think President Trump's going to go there and talk about the firefighter family, the person who lost his life and obviously the people that were injured. He's going to talk about them. If you look at the invitation, that family is number one on the invitation.Number two, everybody who was injured is on that invitation. This is not -- I know we're in politics, okay? But this is a special moment for America. He's going there to finish the speech he was given when somebody tried to take his life. WOOD JR.: Are you excited? MALDONADO: Somebody wanted to say, you're not going to be president. Somebody else is going to be, and he's not going to let a bullet decide who a president -- he took a bullet for us.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me -- let me let Roy in.WOOD JR.: Are you excited to see Elon Musk at this moment, the moment this grand?

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: You know what?WOOD JR.: Is that who should be sharing --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Let me share something with you. I look at Elon Musk. He's from California. California government ran him out of California which is really bad. Kamala was in California when Elon decided to leave. I mean, Larry Ellison left so this notion, I mean -- I don't want to get this because tomorrow is special. I think tomorrow 's special. Elon is there. And Abby said it very clear. Abby, Abby --

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that's a little bit fair to -- I think that maybe, it's a little bit fair to argue is that this is special. And so, if you look at the email that went out from the Trump team listing who's going, it's everybody. I mean, it's the families of those who are affected.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Right. It's the families.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: It's everybody. But for Elon -- Elon's been behind the scene in Republican politics for quite some time. There's recent reporting that he's been funding a lot of these outside super PACs. He's certainly funding one now for the president. So, as Trump goes and finishes this speech, of course he's going to have one of his biggest votes, the voice of voices.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We got to go. He needs the support from Elon and he needs the money. Everyone stay with me. Coming up next, the panel will give us their nightcaps, including a literal night cap.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We're back and it's time for the "NewsNight" cap. You each have 30 seconds to say your piece. Erin, you're up.

utterances.speaker: PERRINE
utterances.sentences: Yes, Kamala Harris got a very abrupt reminder today of who the 46th president of the United States is when she stepped to the podium at the same time that the president did, and networks had to say, who are we going to cover? And they might cover -- they decide they had to cover the president.She might be the one that steps up after a meeting with Bibi to make quick remarks or after visiting the hurricane to make quick remarks, but she reminded today by the White House, who is sitting in the Oval Office.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The President speaks, the President speaks.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Got to say, seen a lot of discussion about this. A lot of us were alive and around for when this trial was going on, but I do think they are correct. You probably should look into whether or not the Menendez Brothers trial would've been a little differently if we had known a few different things. After 30-something years in jail, I'm okay if you give it a second look. You don't necessarily have to change it, but you might want to give it a look.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Interesting. Go ahead, Roy.WOOD JR.: I just want to say thank you to Jordan Seidhom who was the pilot who volunteered his helicopter to try and rescue people in the hurricane relief efforts earlier this week and last week. And also thank you to Dolly Parton, who donated a million dollars to the hurricane relief efforts. Do not forget the people down there in the South, they need our help.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, we love citizen servants. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: Just in closing, I have to disclose that my family does own a small winery.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You're from California, so --

utterances.speaker: MALDONADO
utterances.sentences: But it's definitely in California. But it's wine. It's wine. And the wine industry is going through some very difficult times. Foreign wines coming in and being blended. Inflation, cost of cork bottles, everything's expensive. So, drink more wine. When times are good, drink wine. When times are bad, you can drink more wine.
